p: Okra, also known as ladiesâ€™ fingers, is obtained from the plant Abelmoschus esculentus (L.) Moech. The fruit is highly nutritional and is rich in carbohydrates, proteins, minerals, and vitamins [ 42]. Okra is popular due to the presence of mucilage. The mucilage is rich in random coil polysaccharides. The okra mucilage polysaccharide (OMP) is composed of the sugars galactose, rhamnose, and galacturonic acid [ 42]. Pectin is the major component of OMP. Similar to other polysaccharides, OMP is nontoxic, biodegradable, and cheap. It also exhibits viscosity building properties. It has been used in conjunction with corn starch and carboxymethyl cellulose to develop edible films [ 42, 43].
